Jefferies lifts Coronado Global PT after production beat; flags liquidity crunch
data.description:
** Analysts at Jefferies lift PT on Australia's Coronado Global Resources to A$0.32 from A$0.30; maintain stock rating at "hold"

** Says Q3 saleable production was a 14% beat compared to its estimates as contributions from Buchanan and Mammoth operations commenced

** Says operations continue to be constrained by market conditions, and liquidity remains the key near-term focus for CRN

** Expects the next logical liquidity level to be a partial asset selldown or divesting a non-core asset

** CRN closed Thursday over 20% higher at A$0.35

** Six of nine analysts rate the stock "hold", three "sell" - data compiled by LSEG

** Stock down 54.3% YTD

data.title: Alphatec beatsÂ Q3 revenue expectations, raises full-year revenue guidance
data.description:
Overview

  • Alphatec Q3 revenue grew 30% to $197 mln, beating analyst expectations

  • Adjusted EBITDA for Q3 was $26 mln, surpassing analyst estimates

  • Company raises full-year revenue and profitability guidance

Outlook

  • Alphatec raises full-year revenue guidance to $760 mln from $742 mln

  • Company expects full-year adjusted EBITDA of $91 mln, up from $83 mln

Result Drivers

  • SURGICAL REVENUE - Co attributes 31% growth in surgical revenue to continued momentum of PTP and LTP solutions

  • EOS REVENUE - EOS revenue grew by 29% YoY as EOS Insight adoption increased

  • NEW SURGEON USERS - Achieved 26% growth in net new surgeon users, a key leading indicator of future growth

data.title: Motorola beats Q3 sales, profit expectations
data.description:
Overview

  • Motorola Q3 2025 sales grow 8% yr/yr, beating analyst expectations

  • Adjusted EPS for Q3 2025 beats consensus

Outlook

data.title: Park Hotels Q3 net loss $14 mln
data.description:
Overview

  • Park Hotels Q3 net loss of $14 mln, with diluted loss per share at $0.08

  • Comparable RevPAR decreased 6.1% yr/yr

  • Company increased liquidity to $2.1 bln

Outlook

  • Company projects fourth-quarter group revenue pace to increase over 12% vs. 2024

  • Park expects Hilton Hawaiian Village to see nearly 57% rise in group revenue pace

  • Company revises full-year 2025 Comparable RevPAR to $184-$185

Result Drivers

  • SOFTER DEMAND - Park attributes Q3 RevPAR decline to softer leisure and government transient demand and tough comparisons from last year's strong citywide calendars

  • STRONG MARKET PERFORMANCE - Strong performance in San Francisco, Puerto Rico, New York, Orlando, and Key West partially offset RevPAR declines

  • BALANCE SHEET STRATEGY - Park focused on preserving a strong balance sheet, increasing liquidity to $2.1 bln to address maturing loans

Key Details

data.title: Twilio beats Q3 revenue, adjusted EPS estimates
data.description:
Overview

  • Twilio Q3 revenue rises 15% yr/yr, beating analyst expectations

  • Adjusted EPS for Q3 beats consensus, reflecting strong financial performance

  • Company repurchased $349.8 mln in shares, showing financial confidence

Outlook

  • Twilio raises FY25 revenue growth forecast to 12.4%-12.6% from 10%-11%

  • Company expects FY25 non-GAAP income from operations of $900-$910 mln

  • Twilio projects Q4 revenue between $1.31 bln and $1.32 bln

Result Drivers

  • BROAD-BASED CUSTOMER STRENGTH - Twilio experienced strong growth across customer segments, including startups, enterprises, and ISVs, driving revenue increase

  • INCREASED PROFITABILITY - Non-GAAP income from operations rose 29% yr/yr, reflecting improved operational efficiency and customer engagement

  • EXPANSION RATE IMPROVEMENT - Dollar-based net expansion rate increased to 109%, indicating successful upselling and cross-selling

data.title: US stocks spooked by AI spending concerns, Powell's hawkish tone
data.description:
Key points:
  • Main US indexes end red; Nasdaq falls ~1.6%
  • Cons Disc weakest S&P 500 sector; Real Estate leads gainers
  • Dollar gains; gold up ~2.5%; crude slips; bitcoin loses ~4.5%
  • US 10-Year Treasury yield rises to ~4.09%

US STOCKS SPOOKED BY AI SPENDING CONCERNS, POWELL'S HAWKISH TONE

U.S. stocks dropped on Thursday amid worries over surging AI spending, while investors also digested a more hawkish tone from the U.S. Federal Reserve.

Meanwhile, a widely anticipated trade agreement between U.S. President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping appeared to do little to boost stocks on the day.

The Dow Jones Composite (.DJA) and the S&P 500 Industrial sector both hit record intraday highs, but couldn't hold their gains. Both ended down on the day.

Meta Platforms shares plunged more than 11% after the social media company forecast "notably larger" capital expenses next year, thanks to investments in artificial intelligence.

Microsoft dipped about 3% after the tech giant reported a record capital expenditure of nearly $35 billion for its fiscal first quarter and warned that spending would rise this year.

That said, Alphabet rose 2.5% on Thursday as steady growth in the advertising business and cloud computing powered better-than-expected results.

Overall, the Magnificent Seven ETF was an underperformer on the day, sliding 3.1%. Investors are focusing on quarterly numbers from two more members of the group as Apple and Amazon.com are reporting after the close.

The results followed the Federal Reserve's delivery on Wednesday of a widely expected quarter-point rate cut, before Chair Jerome Powell then raised doubts about future policy moves when in his press conference he said that a December cut was not a "foregone conclusion."

The CME FedWatch Tool now puts the odds of a December rate cut at about 73% vs just over 90% one week ago.

In any event, despite the market's post-FOMC letdown, Craig Cohen, Managing Director, Global Investment Opportunities Group at J.P. Morgan pointed out Wednesday in a Market Intelligence Briefing that yesterday's rate cut was the fifth time that the Fed reduced its target rate with the S&P 500 index at all-time highs.

He notes that in all prior instances, the S&P 500 was higher a year later with an average return of 20%. The worst one-year return was a 15% advance which occurred last year.

Here is a snapshot of where markets stood just shortly after 4 p.m. ET:

(Terence Gabriel)

*****

data.title: Amazon beats Q3 net sales, EPS estimates
data.description:
Overview

  • Amazon Q3 2025 net sales grow 13% yr/yr, beating analysts' expectations, driven by AWS and international segments

  • Adjusted EPS for Q3 beats consensus, reflecting strong operational performance

  • Company's operating income impacted by special charges, net income rises significantly

Outlook

  • Amazon expects Q4 2025 net sales between $206.0 bln and $213.0 bln

  • Company anticipates Q4 2025 operating income between $21.0 bln and $26.0 bln

  • Amazon's guidance includes a favorable FX impact of 190 basis points

Result Drivers

  • AWS GROWTH - AWS sales increased 20% yr/yr, driven by strong demand for AI and core infrastructure, according to CEO Andy Jassy

  • INTERNATIONAL SALES - International segment sales rose 14% yr/yr, aided by favorable foreign exchange rates

  • SPECIAL CHARGES - Operating income impacted by $2.5 bln legal settlement and $1.8 bln severance costs
